content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Use the Cambridge Dictionary to understand the rules for forming and using comparative and superlative adjectives in English Grammar, including example sentences.  Please interact with https://dictionary.cambridge.org/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Click [875]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Scroll WINDOW; down

Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Click [7480]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Open the “Comparative and superlative adjectives” topic to view the rules and examples.
Action: Click [15756]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Click [15756]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Scroll a bit further to ensure the “Comparative and superlative adjectives” link is fully in view before clicking.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Open the “Comparative and superlative adjectives” page to view the grammar rules and examples.
Action: Click [15756]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To gather detailed formation rules, open “Comparison: adjectives (bigger, biggest, more interesting)”.
Action: Click [23263]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Scroll a bit to ensure the “Comparison: adjectives (bigger, biggest, more interesting)” link is properly in view, then try clicking again.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Open the detailed “Comparison: adjectives (bigger, biggest, more interesting)” page for the specific rules.
Action: Click [23263]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Scroll further down to capture the detailed formation rules for comparatives and superlatives.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Continue scrolling to gather more formation details (spelling rules, multi‑syllable adjectives, irregular forms) further down the article.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: More rules (adjectives ending in –y, two‑syllable adjectives, irregular forms) are likely below; continue scrolling down the article.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Additional sections (e.g., adjectives ending in –y or multi‑syllable adjectives using more/most) will be further down; need to keep scrolling to collect the remaining rules and examples.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: More sections (two‑syllable adjectives ending in –y, longer adjectives with more/most, use of ‘than’, definite article with superlatives, etc.) are likely further down. Keep scrolling to capture them.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There are still additional sections below (e.g., other two‑syllable adjectives, longer adjectives that take more/most, using “than”, word order, etc.). Let’s scroll further to capture the remaining rules.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There are further sections describing longer adjectives that use more/most, fixed comparisons, use of “than”, “the”, “one of the”, etc. I should scroll further to capture the rest of the rules.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.

ANSWER; 
Cambridge Dictionary – Summary of the main rules for forming and using comparative and superlative adjectives (with examples taken from the Grammar page “Comparison: adjectives – bigger, biggest, more interesting”):

1. One–syllable adjectives  
   • Add –er for the comparative and –est for the superlative.  
     tall → taller → (the) tallest  
     cheap → cheaper → (the) cheapest  
   • If the adjective ends in a single vowel + single consonant, double the final consonant before adding –er/–est.  
     big → bigger → biggest  
     thin → thinner → thinnest  

2. Adjectives ending in –e  
   • Just add –r / –st.  
     late → later → latest  

3. Two‑syllable adjectives ending in –y  
   • Change –y to –i and add –er / –est.  
     happy → happier → happiest  
     busy → busier → busiest  
   Example: “Are you happier now that you’ve changed your job?”

4. Some other two‑syllable adjectives (often ending in an unstressed vowel sound) can also take –er / –est:  
   clever → cleverer → cleverest; quiet → quieter → quietest; narrow → narrower → narrowest; simple → simpler → simplest  
   Example: “The guest bedroom is the quietest room in the house.”

5. Two‑syllable adjectives ending in –ful and most adjectives of three or more syllables  
   • Form the comparative with more/less and the superlative with most/least.  
     useful → more useful → (the) most useful  
     careful → more careful → (the) most careful  
     interesting → more interesting → (the) most interesting  
   Example: “This dictionary is more useful than the one we had before.”  
   Example: “London is the most popular tourist destination in England.”

6. Irregular forms  
   good → better → best  
   bad → worse → worst  
   far → farther/further → farthest/furthest  
   Example: “Pluto is the furthest planet from the sun in our solar system.”

7. Never use more/most together with an –er/–est form:  
   ✗ “a more better life”  → ✓ “a better life”  
   ✗ “the most biggest beach” → ✓ “the biggest beach”

8. Intensifying or softening comparatives  
   • Strengthen with much, a lot, far, even, rather, etc.:  
     “This food is much better than the food we had yesterday.”  
   • Soften with a little / a bit (less formal):  
     “She feels a little more confident now.”

9. Using than with comparatives  
   • The word than usually follows comparative adjectives to introduce the second element of comparison:  
     “We were busier last week than this week.”  

10. Using the definite article with superlatives  
    • Superlatives normally take the before them:  
      “That was the easiest exam I’ve ever taken.”  
    • To express membership of a group, use one of the + superlative + plural noun:  
      “Marmaris beach is one of the biggest in Turkey.”

11. less / least comparatives and superlatives  
    • less + adjective for a weaker comparison; least + adjective for the superlative of small degree:  
      “That way is less complicated.”  
      “This is the least harmful chemical.”

These points cover the principal Cambridge Grammar rules for forming and using comparative and superlative adjectives, together with authentic example sentences supplied by the dictionary.
Format ERROR: Both 'Thought' and 'Action' should be included in your reply.

Thought: I have collected all key Cambridge Grammar rules and example sentences for forming and using comparative and superlative adjectives.  
Action: ANSWER;  
Cambridge Dictionary – Rules for Comparative and Superlative Adjectives (with examples)

1. One‑syllable adjectives  
   • Add –er (comparative) and –est (superlative).  
     tall → taller → (the) tallest; cheap → cheaper → cheapest.  
   • If a one‑syllable adjective ends vowel + consonant, double the final consonant: big → bigger → biggest; thin → thinner → thinnest.

2. Adjectives ending in –e  
   • Add –r / –st.  
     late → later → latest.

3. Two‑syllable adjectives ending in –y  
   • Change –y to –i and add –er / –est.  
     happy → happier → happiest; busy → busier → busiest.  
     Example: “Are you happier now that you’ve changed your job?”

4. Other two‑syllable adjectives that can take –er / –est  
   clever → cleverer → cleverest; quiet → quieter → quietest; narrow → narrower → narrowest; simple → simpler → simplest.  
   Example: “The guest bedroom is the quietest room in the house.”

5. Two‑syllable adjectives ending in –ful and most adjectives of three or more syllables  
   • Use more/less (comparative) and most/least (superlative).  
     useful → more useful → (the) most useful; interesting → more interesting → (the) most interesting.  
     Example: “This dictionary is more useful than the one we had before.”

6. Longer adjectives (three or more syllables)  
   • Comparative = more/less + adjective; Superlative = most/least + adjective.  
     Example: “London is the most popular tourist destination in England.”

7. Irregular forms  
   good → better → best; bad → worse → worst; far → farther/further → farthest/furthest, etc.

8. Do NOT combine more/most with –er/–est forms  
   ✗ “more better” → ✓ “better”; ✗ “the most biggest” → ✓ “the biggest.”

9. Using than with comparatives  
   • than introduces the second element: “We were busier last week than this week.”

10. Definite article with superlatives  
    • Normally use the: “That was the easiest exam I’ve ever taken.”  
    • For membership of a group: one of the + superlative: “It’s one of the most beautiful cities.”

11. less / least for weaker comparison  
    • less + adjective; least + adjective: “That route is less complicated.” / “This is the least harmful chemical.”

12. Intensifying or softening comparatives  
    • Strengthen with much, a lot, far, even, rather, than ever: “This food is much better than yesterday’s.”  
    • Soften with a little / a bit: “She feels a little more confident now.”

These points sum up the Cambridge Grammar guidance on how English comparative and superlative adjectives are formed and used, together with illustrative sentences.
